51138: Guardian Idol.author: SAUS3
51138: Guardian Idol.text_parsed:
I love this card. I use it in my Vish Kal EDH deck and my Tajic EDH deck.

In my Vish Kal deck, I use it as ramp (since that deck needs all the ramp it can get), and as an emergency chump for eating with my commander. Being able to shoot it at something for just 2 mana to activate is quite useful.

In my Tajic deck, it ramps out my commander on turn 3 and helps activate battalion in the later stages of the game.

I think people undervalue this card. It is basically rampant growth for colourless, but can become a creature instead of thinning your deck/colour fixing.

51160: Eon Hub.author: Lyoncet
51160: Eon Hub.text_parsed:
This spell is my inner blue Johnny's hottest dreams come true. While combos including this card are often prohibitive since they're essentially worthless until you get out your Hub, they're pretty brutal. Consider:

Pact of Negation turns into a poor man's (better!) Force of Will
Living Tsunami/Waterspout Djinn turn into 4/4 fliers for 4 with no drawback
Unstable Mutation becomes a Giant Growth aura for U
Icy Prison turns into Journey to Nowhere (what? Permanent spot removal for blue???)
Ertai's Meddling exiles any spell for 1U.

Your cumulative upkeep spells get pretty badly broken too. Illusionary Wall, Mystic Remora, Illusions of Grandeur, Illusionary Terrain, Survivor of the Unseen the list just goes on. And although your opponent is getting the same benefits, the chances that they've also built an entire deck around not having upkeeps is pretty remote.

I guess you could say that Eon Hub's greatest accomplishment is making the Ice Age block playable.

I give this a 5/5, simply because it completely changes the game!

Almost every strategy is affected. Seriously, if you look at your deck, unless it's simply a powerup strategy, You'll find something that will no longer work. I've been playing this game for a long time, and i've never seen a card with so much staying power, versatility, nor one that ruins so many strategies just by being in play.

This is my favourite card, because i can't remember how many times i've said "This will be totally killed by eon hub."

51160: Eon Hub.author: Haywood
51160: Eon Hub.text_parsed:
Cannot... think... brain going into combo overload...

Less obvious combo cards: Elkin Bottle and Grinning Totem give you cards you can play at any time that are not in your hand (and hence immune to discarding). Sadly enough Three Wishes does not, because it only allows you to play the cards "until your next turn". As for other combos, just search Gatherer for any card mentioning upkeep. Anything with echo or cumulative upkeep is a good bet.

It also stops most alternate-win condition decks, since most of those cards use "at the beginning of your upkeep" (the exceptions being Biovisionary, Coalition Victory, Laboratory Maniac, Maze's End and, of course, The Cheese Stands Alone).

This should be "destroy on sight" material if your opponent plays it. It doesn't matter what they're going to use it for, they can't possibly be up to anything good. Steal it or get rid of it, but don't let it sit there.

I use this in a Child of Alara EDH deck that primarily looks to Maze's End for its win condition. If for whatever reason this sticks on the board (usually because I've dropped a Naked Singularity or Ritual of Subdual first), Glacial Chasm pretty much guarantees I have enough turns to Maze's End my mis-colored/colorless mana into Guildgates.

Even without Eon Hub any one of these is dangerous in an EDH game, but with Eon Hub out they become deadly.

51163: Rite of Passage.author: endersblade
51163: Rite of Passage.text_parsed:
Using this with the Phantom creatures doesn't make a whole lot of sense, Kryptnyt. You prevent the damage, remove a counter, then add a counter. 1 - 1 + 1 = 1. If you remove the last counter, reducing the creature to a 0/0, he would die before you got to put the +1/+1 counter on it from Rite of Passage. I have a Phantom deck, and there are much better ways to abuse their ability.

I currently run this + Pestilence in my EDH deck. Very nice combo. Wipes the board, and turns your creatures into absolute monsters.

51166: Auriok Salvagers.author: Jelf
51166: Auriok Salvagers.text_parsed:
Very versatile card because of the amount of CMC artifacts of 1 or less.

For Casual Play or Peasant Tournament I decided to compile a list of the artifacts (excluding rares or expensive cards) you can have fun with. Its not exhaustive. I just pulled up a 1 CMC or less artifact search with Gatherer. If I made a mistake with the mana costs, forgive me. It's a longish list. The mana cost is the cost to get the effect you want plus the mana needed to bring it back from the grave.

With the Spellbombs per turn
Aether = (4 mana - creature bounce) or (4 mana - card draw)
Sunbeam = (4 mana - gain 5 life) or (4 mana - card draw)
LIfespark = (4 mana - 1 land become 3/3 creatures) or (4 mana - card draw)
-------if the land is an artifact land, then the land is sac-able
Pyrite = (4 mana - 2 damage to target creature or player) or (4 mana - card draw)
Necrogen = (4 mana - Target player discards a card) or (4 mana - card draw)
The Spellbombs are pretty efficient for something you can now use every turn. Aether and Sunbeam are always good together just because of the colors' senergy. Going more than three types of spellbombs and you start to lose effectiveness and waste space in your library. Pyrite is great late in the game because it has the same abilities as Alladin's Ring, except that late in the game if you can generate more mana you can keep pumping Pyrite.

Auriok Salvager+1 CMC artifact creature = 4 mana-1/1 sac-able creature every turn

Auriok Salvager+ Soldevi Sentry+Daru Warchief = 2 mana-2/3 sac-able creature every turn, Veteran's Armaments works well here; senergy with soldier deck

Auriok Salvager+Yotian Soldier+2 Daru Warchief = 3 mana-3/5 sac-able Vigilant creature every turn, Veteran's Armaments works well here; senergy with soldier deck

Auriok Salvager+Soldier Replica+2 Daru Warchief = 3 mana-3/5 sac-able creature every turn with a sac effect of 3 damage to target attacking or blocking creature; senergy with soldier deck

Auriok Salvager+ Arcbound Worker = (3 mana=sac-able 1/1 creature with a sac effect of Put +1/+1 counter on target artifact creature)

Auriok Salvager+Ornithopter = 2 mana-0/2 sac-able flying creature

Auriok Salvager+ Court Homunculus+any artifact = (3 mana - 2/2 sac-able creature)

Auriok Salvager+ Braidwood Sextant or Wanderer's Twig = garunteed land in hand every turn

Auriok Salvager+ Wayfarer's Bauble = garunteed extra land in play per turn

Auriok Salvager+Chromatic Sphere = (4 mana-1 mana of your choice and draw a card); of course you would not pay the salvage cast on the turn you got your colored mana nor would you use the effect on the turn you cast the Sphere, unless you just want the card draw.

Auriok Salvager+Terrarion= 5 mana-2 mana of your choice and combination and then draw a card; same applies with Chromic Sphere

Auriok Salvager+Conjurer's Bauble = (3 mana-put card in your graveyard on the bottom of library, draw a card)

Auriok Salvager+ Dispeller's Capsule= (6 mana-reusable Disenchant)

Auriok Salvager+ Executioner's Capsule = 5 mana-reusable Doom Blade

Auriok Salvager+Lantern of Insight = 3 mana-irritate the crap out of your opponent or (6 mana-irritate 'em twice)



Auriok Salvager+Scrabbling Claws= 4 mana-exile two cards from opponent graveyard and draw a card

Going more than three types of spellbombs and you start to lose effectiveness and waste space in your library.  Pyrite is great late in the game because it has the same abilities as Alladin's Ring, except that late in the game if you can generate more mana you can keep pumping Pyrite.

Auriok Salvager+1 CMC artifact creature = 4 mana-1/1 sac-able creature every turn

Auriok Salvager+ Soldevi Sentry+Daru Warchief = 2 mana-2/3 sac-able creature every turn,  Veteran's Armaments works well here; senergy with soldier deck

Auriok Salvager+Yotian Soldier+2 Daru Warchief =  3 mana-3/5 sac-able Vigilant creature every turn,  Veteran's Armaments works well here; senergy with soldier deck

Auriok Salvager+Soldier Replica+2 Daru Warchief =  3 mana-3/5 sac-able creature every turn with a sac effect of 3 damage to target attacking or blocking creature; senergy with soldier deck

Auriok Salvager+ Arcbound Worker = (3 mana=sac-able 1/1 creature with a sac effect of Put +1/+1 counter on target artifact creature)

Auriok Salvager+Ornithopter = 2 mana-0/2 sac-able flying creature

Auriok Salvager+ Court Homunculus+any artifact = (3 mana - 2/2 sac-able creature) 

Auriok Salvager+ Braidwood Sextant or Wanderer's Twig  = garunteed land in hand every turn

Auriok Salvager+ Wayfarer's Bauble = garunteed extra land in play per turn

Auriok Salvager+Chromatic Sphere = (4 mana-1 mana of your choice and draw a card); of course you would not pay the salvage cast on the turn you got your colored mana nor would you use the effect on the turn you cast the Sphere, unless you just want the card draw.

Auriok Salvager+Terrarion= 5 mana-2 mana of your choice and combination and then draw a card; same applies with Chromic Sphere

Auriok Salvager+Conjurer's Bauble = (3 mana-put card in your graveyard on the bottom of library, draw a card)

Auriok Salvager+ Dispeller's Capsule= (6 mana-reusable Disenchant)

Auriok Salvager+ Executioner's Capsule = 5 mana-reusable Doom Blade

Auriok Salvager+Lantern of Insight  = 3 mana-irritate the crap out of your opponent or (6 mana-irritate 'em twice)



Auriok Salvager+Scrabbling Claws= 4 mana-exile two cards from opponent graveyard and draw a card

51178: Night's Whisper.author: JaxsonBateman
51178: Night's Whisper.text_parsed:
Personally, I'd say it's better than Sign in Blood - sure, Sign in Blood lets you potentially burn an opponent in a monoblack deck, but Night's Whisper is just much more splashable which is typically going to be more useful (when considering the monoblack option, you have to consider how many monoblack decks you'd make with Sign in Blood, and how many would involve a player being on only 2 life without an alternate way to finish the job like a creature - then when considering the splash option, you only need to consider how many Bx decks you'd make with Night's Whisper, and how unlikely they are to have access to BB on turn 2 and still function comfortably afterwards).

However, given that it's been printed recently and in core sets, Sign in Blood is certainly more accessible to players who currently have neither card. :-)

51178: Night's Whisper.author: blurrymadness
51178: Night's Whisper.text_parsed:
Reasons to prefer this in legacy:
-Colorless lands => Wasteland, Dust Bowl, Mutavault, Mishra's Factory

-Multicolor => Same as above, except that you want to reliably cast things. This is why most of the powerhouse creatures in legacy are not only powerful, but color-light.

-It doesn't target; so misdirection can't steal my cards; which can happen.


Yeah, there will be a game now and then where you miss out killing the opponent because you needed 2 life to live or they have 2 life left and you couldn't burn them. However, there will be many more games where misdirection or color screw cause you to lose since you couldn't find the cards you needed.

Again, this is seriously helpful when all you draw is Swamp Wasteland in your opener; as it allows you to crawl out of the mana-screw rather easily.

51180: Magma Jet.author: Stray_Dog
51180: Magma Jet.text_parsed:
Cool card. I think I see what the scrying is hinting at, but it would be cool to see the new red looting mechanic combined with burn in the same card. Maro reckons Faithless Looting isn't quite what red looting will end up looking like. I presume red wants to dump first then draw, which is the opposite of what blue wants to do. If Faithless Looting is a one mana flashback card that loots two cards each time, perhaps something like this could see print:

Eject |
Uncommon
Instant
Discard a card, then draw a card.
Eject deals 3 damage to target creature or player.
Out with the old and in with the new.

The flavour of the spell is that the caster is 'ejecting' one of their prepared spells as a blast of raw mana. Dumping the unwanted spell is a cathartic act, providing new inspiration.
51180: Magma Jet.text_posted:

51183: Neurok Stealthsuit.author: Aaron_Forsythe
51183: Neurok Stealthsuit.text_parsed:
Aaron's Random Card Comment of the Day #31, 11/8/10

Both Scars of Mirrodin and all the sets in the original Mirrodin block contain many artifact cards with colored mana symbols on them. (Im pleased that the ones in Scars are actually, you know, colored as opposed to the grayed-out ones on the cards from the original Mirrodin block, which were that way because of a long-since-solved printing complication created when we switched to the newer card frames.) We include so many colored-activated artifacts to both broaden what artifacts are capable of and to narrow what decks they go it. As anyone that has played a fair bit of Scars sealed deck recently can attest to, a huge number of purely colorless cards can be daunting to evaluate. Hopefully the colored mana symbols help give direction.

Ideally, artifacts with colored mana symbols still function in a deck that cant generate that color of mana, but are way better in decks that can. Just about all of them fit that model, with there being a few rare (literally) exceptions, such as Proteus Staff. Neurok Stealthsuit fits the typical mold.

Mark Rosewater initially proposed the cycle of equipment with colored instant equip abilities for Mirrodin proper, but it was right not to include them in the set that debuted equipment. They were correctly saved for a couple sets to let players get their heads around how equipment worked normally before throwing this twist at them. This cycle, by the way, is pretty embarrassing due to how disparately powered they are. Im sure most of you are familiar with Cranial Plating.

I doubt wed print this card today as a common, as we have been consciously trying to cut down on common on-board tricks, as they lead to some real feel-bad moments. Nothing feels as bad a casting a spell at a creature only to have your opponent pay to give it shroud with a card you should have realized was in play. Magic is hard enough without this kind of slap-you-in-the-face occurrence happening frequently.

To tie this discussion back to some of my previous card comments, when I say stuff like R&D is currently down on on-board tricks, or shuffling, or counterspells, or tutors, or whatever, that doesnt mean were trying to expunge them from the game. We know people like them. We keep printing them. Heck, M11 had Infantry Veteran, Fauna Shaman, and Mana Leak, just to name a card from each category. It just means that we need to be conscious of how many of them are in an environment, which wasnt always true of how we did things in the past. Lorwyn block, for instance, is loaded with on-board tricks because we werent thinking about them at all, and the limited environment suffered greatly because of it. Whatever the cool, dangerous thing is that you enjoy, we want to make sure were giving you just the right amount of it to keep Magic fun and you happy.

51183: Neurok Stealthsuit.author: alextfish
51183: Neurok Stealthsuit.text_parsed: I love on-board tricks. I loved the Lorwyn limited environment, and I hadn't quite realised that was part of why, but I'm sure it was. I do particularly like it when a card can grant shroud/protection at instant speed, but not too easily. Leonin Shikari + Lightning Greaves is too easy (once you get the cards out) - it just becomes impossible to target anything. But {U}{U} is a sensible cost for it: the player can't do it very much, especially if blue isn't their only colour, so the opponent still has a hope of managing to target things sometimes. I like Neurok Stealthsuit and still use it in my decks from time to time.

51183: Neurok Stealthsuit.author: ProfN
51183: Neurok Stealthsuit.text_parsed:
"As anyone that has played a fair bit of Scars sealed deck recently can attest to, a huge number of purely colorless cards can be daunting to evaluate."

Huh? I don't get this, Aaron. When worrying about whether you'll have the colors to cast spells is taken out of the equation, I find it much easier to eval a sealed pool. Just compare CMC to power/tough and effectiveness and look at your curve. Where I find the challenge in evaluating Scars sealed pools is deciding whether I have what it takes to go Infect, and if not, whether I have sufficiently aggressive creatures to try to be the beatdown against non-Infect strategies or whether I need to go a controlling route (ugh).

As for Lorwyn Block, that was one of my favorite blocks for Limited games and it was *because* of the on-board tricks - it was a real skill-tester and often my opponents were found wanting. Later formats that lacked such a density of on-board tricks are more strictly about "did you maintain discipline during drafting / did you open a good sealed pool, and did you build your deck correctly?" Without much on-board interaction the decks then tend to play themselves too much for my taste. :(

51183: Neurok Stealthsuit.author: spirit_of_blue
51183: Neurok Stealthsuit.text_parsed:
At least 2 people in comments compared this to Cranial Plating and mentioned that Cranial Plating is obviously superior to Neurok Stealthsuit.

Honestly I disagree. Both equipements are doing principially differend things and hardly can be compared. And even if plating is doing things that will be more appreciated in majority of players, I would still disagree. In my opinion, because of big principial difference between those two cards, evaluating them strongly depends on type of player.

At example plating is really useful only in artifact decks, but stealthsuit could fit well to deck where it is the only artifact. What would plating do in such deck? Not much. Also imagine stealthsuit in EDH deck where number of copies is limited to 1. With this card, player has virtually unlimited number of copies of counters. Only thing he has to care about is enough mana.

In my opinion superiority of plating over stealthsuit is definitely not obvious. It always depends on type of player and type of deck. Different preferations for Timmy and Johnny.

51183: Neurok Stealthsuit.author: HedronMyr
51183: Neurok Stealthsuit.text_parsed:
@ Spirit_of_blue

I definitely see what you're saying, and this could be really nice with certain decks (Something that runs Master Transmuter for example) so nothing short of a wrath effect can stop you from cheating things into play. However, Cranial Plating is a really powerful offensive bomb that can almost singlehandledly turn the tide in the player's favor due to the sheer firepower it brings, especially if equipped onto something like Vault Skirge, Etched Champion.

Not to say this card is bad or that it even has no use. It's a good card with some good applications in the right deck as I've said. Cranial Plating certainly has more board impact though: if the opponent can't do something about Plating, they're probably going to lose.

51186: Horned Helm.author: Hercynian
51186: Horned Helm.text_parsed:
One of the more fun equipments out there because you can pass it around your monsters like a soccer ball. For example, I attack my opponent with my 3/3 (+1/+1) monster that has trample thanks to this puppy so my opponent takes that in lieu of futilely blocking with his 3/3. Then, when my opponent swings back with said 3/3 I can block with my 2 llanowar elves, tap them to equip the helmet to one of them, and unexpectedly kill his 3/3.

It's not the best equipment for sure, it's no sword. But it's fun and has a cheap equip cost to synergize with creatures that take advantage of that. Your opponents will forget about it more often than you'd think, and that +1/+1 boost really makes a difference.

Even without the colored insta-shift, this thing is colorless trample-granting & +1/+1. So it's good for that reason as well.

51229: Grinding Station.author: Velacteis
51229: Grinding Station.text_parsed:
Combo this + Summoning Station + Mycosynth Lattice

Tap summoning station to put a 2/2 colorless pincher token into play. Because Mycosynth Lattice makes it an artifact you are able to sacrifice it to Grinding Station. The artifact leaving play allows you to untap summoning station. Tap it again to put another 2/2 colorless artifact creature into play. Wash rinse repeat for a win on their draw step.

The artifact leaving play allows you to untap summoning station.  Tap it again to put another 2/2 colorless artifact creature into play.  Wash rinse repeat for a win on their draw step.

51229: Grinding Station.author: PeabodyET
51229: Grinding Station.text_parsed: If you get this and a Salvaging Station in play with a Flayer Husk in the graveyard (or in play with his germ token), you can infinite mill. You use the Salvaging Station to put the Husk into play and you get a free germ token. The Husk untaps the Grinding Station. You use the Grinding Station to sacrifice the Husk and mill. The germ token dies due to having 0 toughness, which untaps the Salvaging Station. Rinse and repeat.

51229: Grinding Station.author: VarteDod
51229: Grinding Station.text_parsed:
Step 1:
Tap this and sacrifice a noncreature artifact with CMC 1 or less:
Mills three cards and untaps Summoning Station.
Step 2:
Tap Summoning Station:
Gives a 2/2 Pincher and untaps Blasting Station.
Step 3:
Tap Blasting Station and sacrifice the Pincher:
Deals 1 damage to any target and untaps Salvaging Station.
Step 4:
Tap Salvaging Station:
Return the artifact sacrificed at Step 1. Untap this.
Step 5:
Repeat steps 1 - 4 ad infinitum.

*Shrugs* Like most Sunburst cards, it's not the best of cards. In fact I'd call this downright ineffecient. But it's far, far from terrible, guys. Remember you can drop this and use it to your heart's content, and anything that can recharge it can make for a nifty combat trick stick.
Aside from that, yeah, it's pretty underwhelming. Maybe if it had been +2/+2 it would have been superior to the eighteen billion +1/+1 counter generating things in the block, but I digress.

51611: Beacon of Unrest.author: DarthParallax
51611: Beacon of Unrest.text_parsed:
majinara....umm....it's black. You're just wrong.

Mana Cost- Draw Spells
2. Sign in Blood
3. Necropotence
3. Phyrexian Arena
5. Bloodgift Demon
8. Griselbrand

Mana Cost- Tutors
1. Vampiric Tutor
2. Demonic Tutor
4. Diabolic Tutor
7. Rune-Scarred Demon
5/8/13. Increasing Ambition
X. Diabolic Revalations

This isn't particularly comprehensive, but it's 11 strong cards off the top of my head without trying,
And there is a lot more Graveyard Hate than Library Hate. While there is a good amount of milling off the top, there isn't a lot of looking through a player's library for specific stuff and hosing it before they can even draw it. I think Cranial Extraction was the first, maybe Haunting Echoes was. But anyway, if you want to get stuff out of your graveyard, you're going to have to fight against more Hate than if you pick anything else to do. If you want to, you can build an EDH deck that's over 30% Hate Graveyards.

Know why Griselbrand got banned? Because it made Storm so much of a sure thing in EDH it was a 3 turn combo to draw or tutor like your whole deck and then blast everyone at once. In White or Green, your statement would be True. In Blue and Black, Tutors and Draw >> Graveyard pulling. In Red....Red sucks. :P

More cards I haven't said yet:
Skeletal Scrying
Dark Confidant
Greed
Underworld Connections
Infernal Tutor
Death Wish
Dark Tutelage

51628: Eternal Witness.author: Mode
51628: Eternal Witness.text_parsed:
A cip/etb Regrowth trigger on a 2/1 three-drop is definitely playable.
I like the fact most that Wizards did not just make her a 1/1 chump blocker for the increased cost of but even gave her 2 power to make her even more decent.
There are so many possibilities to make use of her triggered ability multiple times.

She also does a great job with Unearth once she's in your graveyard, which will provide you both with her 2/1 body and another card from your graveyard for just - even including Unearth itself!
This combo also has a good synergy with Intuition in case you want a particular card yet do not have three copies of it in your library: Pick the desired card, the Witness and Unearth. This way no matter which of these cards your opponent chooses, you'll ultimately be able to get the one you want, either directly or by putting the Witness into play for either or .

On top of that i'm also very content with the iconic art Terese Nielsen gave this card. You can immediately recognize the card once it hits the board - including the alternate art on the Friday Night Magic promo version.
When considering the fact that this could have pretty much appeared anytime, it surprises me that of all blocks Wizards decided to let us see this card getting printed in Mirrodin.
It's one of a very few cards from this artifact block that does not make me think of Ravager Affinity when i look at it.
Yet regarding flavor you can still recognize that she is located within the Tangle when taking a look at the background.

51628: Eternal Witness.author: Donovan_Fabian
51628: Eternal Witness.text_parsed:
Another one of those cards that they didn't play test enough, its actually ridiculously unfair with simple cards like crystal shard, venser, and etc. You find one card that locks out your opponent, then replay eternal witness repeatedly to use it, and that's game. The typical set up is venser/crystal shard, eternal witness, exhausation. You can also use oris samite guardian + eternal witness to bring back a second copy from the graveyard and discard it repeatedly for her grandeur affect making it so your opponent can no longer play spells the rest of the game.

Can tell that wotc makes a point not to print any more cards like this since we haven't seen anymore return any card affects except for naya charm, and thats on an instant that takes 3 different colored mana and so isn't quite as abusable. Oh and no they should never EVER reprint this card. Any card that locks out your opponent from doing anything as soon as you get two cards in play is over powered, and frankly takes all the enjoyment out of the game. At that point its who gets their uber combo first, and nothing about actually playing the game.

51628: Eternal Witness.author: Calver
51628: Eternal Witness.text_parsed:
Absolutely a powerful card, but not actually broken. I would like it to be reprinted: not so that it can get abused, but rather so that it is more available to casual green decks who could use a little help.

Green genuinely needs either recursion or card advantage. It has had it in different forms (flashback, a little bit of madness, greater good, etc.) and I'm glad its getting cards like these more often. Without it green just gasses way too quickly. There's really nothing wrong with giving green a card like this, especially at 2 green weight. Yes, a good multicolor deck will always have the two green necessary, but it takes preparation to do so consistently, especially if you plan on taxing your resources by bouncing the witness and/or playing the returned spell in the same turn.

Really, an 8 mana lock that requires you to cast multiple spells every round is not actually that powerful. I'd sooner play a turn two exhume on Iona, Shield of Emeria than try to gather a clunky combo focused on this card. There are just too many ways to disrupt such combos.

@LoisianaxLimey

I am not sure on the way it would work, but my interpretation of "double the number of +1/+1 counters on solarion." would translate into "Put a +1/+1 counter on solarion for each counter on solarion."

That would mean:

if you have a doubling season out and solarion has 5 counters on it, you would tap it to add 5 * 2(doubling season) and end up with a 15/15.

if you have a doubling season, then play solarion with max effect of sunburst, he would come into play with 10 counters because of doubling season, then tapping would mean add 10 counters * 2 for the season ending up with a 30/30.

51629: Solarion.text_parsed:
As someone has already mentioned, this dude is mean as a blocker since you can tap him after you declare blockers to double the counters.

However, if you give this dude Vigilance with something like Accorder's Shield you effectively get to use the same strategy while attacking. If they chump block you, don't tap him and you'll still have him as a defender that can double in size. If they let him through or try to kill him, double the counters.

It goes without saying that he's also great with Trample on him, so perhaps the best thing to do is equip him with Sword of Vengeance (+2/+0, First Strike, Vigilance, Trample, Haste).

51629: Solarion.text_parsed:
Heartstone or a similar card to reduce activated ability costs
Voltaic Construct
Solarion, paid for with any number of types of mana.

For an example, say it was paid with 2 mana colours. Assume you have 7 mana (since you played this last turn).
Starts as 2/2.
{T} - 4/4
Pay {1} for VC to untap it.
{T} - 8/8
Pay {1} for VC to untap it.
{T} - 16/16
Pay {1} for VC to untap it.
{T} - 32/32
Pay {1} for VC to untap it.
{T} - 64/64
Pay {1} for VC to untap it.
{T} - 128/128
Pay {1} for VC to untap it.
{T} - 256/256
Pay {1} for VC to untap it.
It is now free to attack.

You get the point; doubling can really be obscenely powerful. Even without the Heartstone, it gets to 16/16 with 3 taps.

51631: Fold into Aether.author: Velacteis
51631: Fold into Aether.text_parsed:
@ Black Mantha

Rule 113.4 "A spell or ability on the stack is an illegal target for itself."

Nice try though...

Another way to do cast this to minimize card disadvantage would be to counter your instant imprinted to isochron scepter. This works because even though you are using an ability to cast it, it goes on the stack as a spell. The isochron scepter's 'ability' goes on the stack, once it resolves it copies a 'spell' onto the stack which you can counter using this card.

I guess the major question would be, how does it weigh against Elvish Piper. This spell is more or less the same mana cost, depending of course on the spell that you are countering. The card disadvantage is also a major factor with this card but there is one thing you have to consider: it's a blue spell. Blue spells have a lot of cheap ways to make up for this disadvantage and blue spells don't usually have a lot of abilities that can put a fatty into play as easily as this can.

Another great advantage that this has over elvish piper is the "Oh shit, I did not see that coming" effect. With Elivish piper they have a whole turn to either respond with a removal spell or to adjust the strategy for what's coming.

Fold into Aether also turns trash cards into "Oh my god, I'm going to frigging pound your face in!" cards, a concept not unlike the ever-popular cycling mechanic.

And lastly, it's a costly counterspell if you desperately need it.

51631: Fold into Aether.author: TheMurderousKitten
51631: Fold into Aether.text_parsed:
@iPreferStormCrow: Overpowered? Really? Your example of how to throw down Emrakul relies on you pulling 4 moxes in your opening hand, plus Emrakul. Most players have probably never even seen 4 moxes, much less have their own playset of them. And pulling 5 specific cards in your opening hand is extremely unlikely, even if you have them in your deck. Please don't call something overpowered simply because there is some extremely unlikely combo that could be powerful one time, assuming the stars line up perfectly that day.

As for the usefulness of this card, no it is not a good counterspell. However, I like the fact that it is a way to cheat in fatties in . Seems like everyone else gets them, just not . The usefulness of this over all of the creature-cheaters mentioned is that this one is mono-blue. Meaning it could go in a mono-blue deck, which I love building. And it means I could cheat out something like Inkwell Leviathan for about half its normal cost. No, it's not going to lead to any turn 3 auto-win decks, but it is still a fun and useful card.

Oh, and did I mention it's an instant? Meaning you can flash in that fattie to block on your opponent's turn? That by itself makes this card useful.

51631: Fold into Aether.author: Totema
51631: Fold into Aether.text_parsed:
An interesting situation where this might be useful:
1. You play a spell. Doesn't really matter which.
2. Opponent plays a counter that has an additional effect. Something nasty like Mana Drain should give you the picture.
3. You counter your first spell with this. Barring any additional interrupts, this resolves first, making your first spell an invalid target for your opponent's counter and keeping the other effect from happening. Plus, you get a free creature. It's usually nowhere great but in weird situations like this it sort of shines.
51631: Fold into Aether.text_posted:
An interesting situation where this might be useful:
1. You play a spell. Doesn't really matter which.
2. Opponent plays a counter that has an additional effect. Something nasty like [autocard]Mana Drain[/autocard] should give you the picture.
3. You counter your first spell with this. Barring any additional interrupts, this resolves first, making your first spell an invalid target for your opponent's counter and keeping the other effect from happening. Plus, you get a free creature. It's usually nowhere great but in weird situations like this it sort of shines.

51633: Krark-Clan Ironworks.author: The_Trendkill
51633: Krark-Clan Ironworks.text_parsed:
The old Standard combo, for those who aren't familiar with it:

Spend the first couple of turns getting down four mana and as many artifacts as possible, ideally six (easily done with Chrome Mox, the artifact lands, the mana myr, and cheap stuff like Ornithopter, Conjurer's Bauble, etc...). When you have four mana available, play Krark-Clan Ironworks. Sacrifice three of your artifacts to the ironworks to make six mana and play Myr Incubator. Then, sacrifice three more artifacts to make six more mana and activate Myr Incubator. Search your library for at least 22 artifacts (again, easily done because almost the entire deck consisted of artifacts, courtesy of the artifact lands) to produce at least 22 1/1 Myr artifact creature tokens. Sacrifice all of them to the ironworks to make 44 colorless mana. Use four of that mana to play Goblin Cannon, and then use the rest of it to activate it 20 times, dealing 20 damage to your opponent. Yes, it does work - the sacrifice is part of the resolution, not the cost.

51633: Krark-Clan Ironworks.author: mdakw576
51633: Krark-Clan Ironworks.text_parsed:
My friend has a Sharuum EDH deck. Aside from maybe Clock of Omens, this is by far the most powerful and degenerate card in the deck.

- It generates tons of mana.
- It lets any of his permanents (save for his Tezzerets and nonartifact lands) dodge removal that isn't krosan grip.
- It gets things in the graveyard for Sharuum to get back to get the enter the battlefield effect again OR things with leave the battlefield effects (such as Ichor Wellspring or Spine of Ish Sah).
- It lets him sac Sharuum so he can recast her in order to get something in the graveyard back.

72681: Plunge into Darkness.author: Heartbreak_two
72681: Plunge into Darkness.text_parsed:
One of the pillars of my deck.

As you know sacrificing a creature doesn't always have to be something negative.
That's why I use this card in combo with Butcher of Malakir.

If I have 3 Butchers in game and if I sacrifice only one of my creatures, the opponent has to sacrifice 3 of his creatures. Then I use Death Denied to put the sacrificed creatures back into my hand. And if these are creatures with kicker & multikicker abilities, I can (multi)kick them all over again :). For instance Bloodhusk Ritualist and Gatekeeper of Malakir. And if I have Lim-Dûl the Necromancer ingame I can get control of the creatures my opponents sacrifices. This only my midgame/lategame strategy though.

72681: Plunge into Darkness.author: Ragamander
72681: Plunge into Darkness.text_parsed:
@ whisperwalk

Agreed...except that it can matter what you found, if you were digging for a copy of Angel's Grace in order to survive the lethal Lightning Bolt that you will soon find directed straight to your face, either as soon as Plunge into Darkness resolves or immediately before Near-Death Experience's trigger gets a chance to resolve. You can only hope (A) that you will manage to dig deep enough to find a copy of Angel's Grace, (B) that your opponent lacks the appropriate cards or the necessary mana to burn you both during his end step and at the beginning of your upkeep, and finally (C) that you are actually looking for a second copy of Angel's Grace, because we all know that your opponent will always have both the second burn spell and the mana to cast it.

So yeah, Plunge into Darkness is actually even better for Near-Death Experience than one may initially think: not only does it let you set your life to 1 at instant speed (making it a win condition that allows only a narrow window of opportunity for your opponent to disrupt the combo), but it also helps you find cards to stop that disruption if they happen to have it. It wins you the game and protects itself. Awesome.

Oh, did I mention that it's also really good for turning your disposable creatures into life and for digging out whatever card you need at the moment (such as a combo-piece that may or may not be related to Near-Death Experience, or answers like Negate) at instant speed, like in response to Wrath of God or at the end of your opponent's turn?

It's also hilarious with Plague of Vermin, or if you're digging for Second Sunrise.

You can only hope (A) that you [i]will[/i] manage to dig deep enough to find a copy of [autocard]Angel's Grace[/autocard], (B) that your opponent lacks the appropriate cards or the necessary mana to burn you both during his end step [i]and[/i] at the beginning of your upkeep, and finally (C) that you are actually looking for a [i]second[/i] copy of [autocard]Angel's Grace[/autocard], because we all know that your opponent will [i]always[/i] have both the second burn spell [i]and[/i] the mana to cast it.

72725: Etched Oracle.author: Lateralis0ne
72725: Etched Oracle.text_parsed:
It's an excellent in-block card. Ramping into four colors with artifacts (especially now, if you count out of block!) is not hard to do at all, and Glimmervoid, the Talismans, the Artifact lands, and all the green color ramping available in Fifth Dawn can allow you to consistently hit this for its full sunburst count on the fourth turn, and I've done it earlier, too. Then, attack until it dies, and blow it up for a Ancestral Recall's worth of cards. As MasterOfEtherium said, a 4/4 for 4 is nothing to shake a stick at.

This sits high on my list of awesome Fifth Dawn cards, and it probably will for a very long time.

Plus, I absolutely love the artwork! Matt Cavotta did a great job here.

72858: Summoning Station.author: Mode
72858: Summoning Station.text_parsed:
Well, the most obvious loop with this card is the combo with the other three stations - possibly the only obviously intentional infinity combo Wizards every created:
Combine Grinding Station, Summoning Station, Salvaging Station and this one.
Sacrifice an artifact and watch prepare for an almost certain victory. Getting this combo out is somewhat utopistic, though.
(By the way, put the four cards next to each other and you'll notice they are one artwork which has been split up: http://www.wizards.com/global/images/mtgcom_daily_af16_picMain_en.jpg)

Another thing, what the hell is a "Pincher"? Why did this not change with the Grand Creature Type Update?
Being produced from a machine on a production line pretty much makes this a Construct, doesn't it?
I'd be more content with a wording like this:
": Put a 2/2 colorless Construct creature token named Pincher onto the battlefield."

72858: Summoning Station.author: JRKarnes88
72858: Summoning Station.text_parsed: @Axer - Tokens DO go to the graveyard. When a token is put into the graveyard it is simply removed from the game as a triggered event. When dealing with creatures and the graveyard the game follows the following logic: "A creature is being put into the graveyard; trigger all 'put into graveyard effects;' if it is a token, remove it from the game"
72858: Summoning Station.text_posted: @Axer - Tokens DO go to the graveyard. When a token is put into the graveyard it is simply removed from the game as a triggered event. 72858: Summoning Station.author: Xlo51
72858: Summoning Station.text_parsed:
1. Play Darksteel Relic.
2. Grinding Station on relic to untap this.
3. Place Pincher token to untap Blasting Station.
4. Blasting Station on Pincher to untap Salvaging Station.
5. Salvage relic to untap Grinding Station.

Use 2 of each to maximize production and help prevent mistakes.

73552: Bringer of the Green Dawn.author: Pigfish99
73552: Bringer of the Green Dawn.text_parsed:
With proper mana acceleration, green decks should not have a hard time getting the green dawn out. Granted, most decks will probably play with 5 colors if they play with the bringers.

The ability that comes with the green bringer is excellent. It works like the Rampaging Baloths, but it is constant, rather than every land drop. Sure, the baloths have a lesser CMC, stronger tokens, and 1 more P/T, but if you get no land drops, you won't get any tokens. Meanwhile, the bringer will just keep on making them. I'd rate them both evenly, In my honest opinion.

73553: Bringer of the Red Dawn.author: Kelrath
73553: Bringer of the Red Dawn.text_parsed:
You may target an untapped creature with an untap effect, just as you may target a creature with a destroy effect even if that creature is indestructible.

If you "untap target creature and gain control of it until end of turn", you untap the creature AND gain control of it, regardless of whether either of those actually has any effect on the targeted card. The only real condition is whether the target can be targeted.
73553: Bringer of the Red Dawn.text_posted:
You may target an untapped creature with an [i]untap[/i] effect, just as you may target a creature with a [i]destroy[/i] effect even if that creature is indestructible.

If you [i]"untap target creature and gain control of it until end of turn"[/i], you untap the creature AND gain control of it, regardless of whether either of those actually has any effect on the targeted card. The only real condition is whether the target can be targeted.

I've also been sad to draw him late and only have four colors...until I realize that I can pay full price!

73557: Composite Golem.author: Lateralis0ne
73557: Composite Golem.text_parsed:
MasterOfEtherium, while not necessary concise in his grammar and syntax, still has it right. This was a auto four-of in my Door to Nothingness combo deck. Running massive card draw off of Skullclamps via Myrs and untap engines like Dross Scorpion (I tried to keep it simple casual and in-block), it was actually quite effective. Enough so to get my foot in the door with my current play group, and to earn their respect as a MTG player before growing exponentially in skill to be in the upper status quo of everyone that plays in that group.

Fun times. But I have fond memories of this card.

73558: Paradise Mantle.author: Ritius
73558: Paradise Mantle.text_parsed:
I've played a lot of decks where this is a part of a combo:

Guilder Bairn with this and a Pentad Prism for inf mana to infinitely boost planeswalkers or whatever else you like to kill with.

Puresight Merrow to scry through your deck instantly until the next card is your winning piece.

With a Freed from the Real on a Goblin Medics for infinite lulz.

I can't remember the others, but there's more. This is basically an Earthcraft for one creature, enabling a lot of the same combos but in a less obviously broken way. Good for any untapping creatures.

73559: Door to Nothingness.author: majinara
73559: Door to Nothingness.text_parsed:
Normally I dislike instant win cards.
This one is kinda funny though. I have it as a one-off in some multiplayer decks of mine, as a final solution to players who decide to get a few hundred life, making all their permanents indestructible or simply annoy me too much. ^^ It costs 15 mana to activate and lies a turn around, so it's in matters of power level a very weak card. But many people simply don't expect it, so it's kinda fun. Especially with Rings of Brightheart.

One advice though: stay clear of willbenders when activating the door. ;)

73559: Door to Nothingness.author: SleetFox
73559: Door to Nothingness.text_parsed:
This is more effective in single player, but it's more fun in multiplayer. I am a big fan of enslaving weakened foes to do my bidding (like a Pokémon, if you will) by holding, say, a Lightning Bolt to their head and threatening to murder them if they don't do what I say. This one doesn't even require you to weaken them (so I guess it's a Master Ball).

It's still a pretty wonky card. It's extremely expensive and telegraphed; for that much mana I'd rather just hardcast Progenitus, who is ALSO almost a certain victory, but is harder to get rid of.
73559: Door to Nothingness.text_posted:

It's still a pretty wonky card.  It's extremely expensive and telegraphed; for that much mana I'd rather just hardcast [autocard]Progenitus[/autocard], who is ALSO almost a certain victory, but is harder to get rid of.

73561: Circle of Protection: Artifacts.author: Notoriety
73561: Circle of Protection: Artifacts.text_parsed:
Just not a great card overall. Besides, it just doesn't feel too White (even though I know all Circles of Protection are white) for this set, which included pro-artifact cards like the Leonin and the Auriok. Additionally, the Bringer of the White Dawn has a pro-artifact ability. Since it was in a cycle, that means the devs felt that being pro-artifact was distinctly White for this set. It would have fit much better with green in the set that has both Tel-Jilad Justice and Viridian Lorebearers.

I don't like the art either, and the flavor text is cheesy.

73561: Circle of Protection: Artifacts.author: DarthParallax
73561: Circle of Protection: Artifacts.text_parsed:
Something tells me that all of these comments from 2009 are saying this is crap because they have no idea of the horrors of "Card Type- Artifact"

You all do realize this almost races Tinker + Darksteel/Blightsteel Colossus?

I'm not sure how this would fare vs. Arcbound Ravager....but, I'm certain it's at least playable.

Yeah- the implementations for this are narrow. It just stops all artifact creatures ever.

"Only good for Mirrodin Block?" That's like saying that Glittering Wish is 'Mainly good because of Ravnica and Alara Block" Yeah. These statements are true. These blocks have powerful cards in them that you are very likely to meet since they are more recent than, say, Antiquities, Legends, or the Dark.

I'm not saying this will automatically save you from Artifact decks and therefore you should go out and run and get four right away. I'm just saying it's massively underrated because the comments don't make sense given how powerful and worth hateboarding against I know Artifacts to be....

73564: Reversal of Fortune.author: majinara
73564: Reversal of Fortune.text_parsed:
Horrible card.
You need an opponent with cards in hand. Then he must have instants or sorceries in hand. Then if he has instants your opponent could play them in response to this spell. And if this spell resolves and your opponent has still sorceries or instants in hand, then they must also be cards that make sense when you play them (no counterspells or similiar). And then the card even ain't discarded or something like that.

This card is just plain horrible.

If you like such effects, play planeswalker's mischief instead. Costs one more to play and activate, but it also discards the card and can be used each turn and as often as you got mana.

73564: Reversal of Fortune.author: sonorhC
73564: Reversal of Fortune.text_parsed:
@CrazyLou, I like the way you think. I think, though, that what happens is this:
1: You cast this spell, putting it on the stack.
2: While this spell is resolving, you cast the counterspell from their hand, targeting this. The counterspell goes on the stack.
3: This finishes resolving before we look at the stack again. When it finishes resolving, it goes to your graveyard.
4: Counterspell tries to resolve. However, since it no longer has a target, it is itself countered, and has no effect (including any extra effect it might have-- Like, if the counter you used was Mana Drain, you wouldn't get any mana from it).

Net effect, you've spent and a card to look at their hand, and nothing else ended up happening.
73564: Reversal of Fortune.text_posted:
@CrazyLou, I like the way you think.  I [i]think[/i], though, that what happens is this:
1:  You cast this spell, putting it on the stack.
2:  While this spell is resolving, you cast the counterspell from their hand, targeting this.  The counterspell goes on the stack.
3:  This finishes resolving before we look at the stack again.  When it finishes resolving, it goes to your graveyard.
4:  Counterspell tries to resolve.  However, since it no longer has a target, it is itself countered, and has no effect (including any extra effect it might have--  Like, if the counter you used was [autocard]Mana Drain[/autocard], you wouldn't get any mana from it).

Net effect, you've spent [4][R][R] and a card to look at their hand, and nothing else ended up happening.

73564: Reversal of Fortune.author: vantha
73564: Reversal of Fortune.text_parsed:
This is an interesting card because, it allows Red to Peek into an opponents hand. This ability on the color pie is usually given to Blue and Black but strange for Red. The other part of this card lets you cast their best sorcery or instant spell.

I see this being good against, Blue, Black, and other Red decks. Most Green and White decks are more creature focused so this card tends to fizzle against them.

And last, the art is awesome. The vulshok shaman is very beautiful and goes to show us that even Red mages can be attrative and deadly at the same time.

73565: Channel the Suns.author: typezeroserodin
73565: Channel the Suns.text_parsed:
The way I usually play this card in my green "stompy deck" (which includes Progenitus, Legacy Weapon, etc), is I play at least 2 helm of awakenings to minimize the cost.

Otherwise, it's really only a mana-conversion card that costs 1 less than the actual effect returns to you. With the helms, I've been able to play Progenitus for two green mana before (on the fourth turn, nonetheless).
These would be a lot nastier if their cost wasn't so stifling for their effect.

Still, a great card; glad I own four of them.

Emrakul is useless unless you have the above two.

Not to mention if you include stuff like Maelstrom Archangel as another way to spend the mana, if she gets blasted you just got 2 for 1.

More power to you if you can make this setup work! But it feels like it would take allot of tinkering to get the numbers right to make it consistent.

Tapping a land that you already used wouldn't really do anything at all. Basically, your spell would still go off.

73571: Early Frost.author: DrQuark
73571: Early Frost.text_parsed: If I tap opponents lands, can they then add mana from those lands to their mana pool?
73571: Early Frost.text_posted: If I tap opponents lands, can they then add mana from those lands to their mana pool?

73571: Early Frost.author: achilleselbow
73571: Early Frost.text_parsed:
Ok, irixio, I think you're mostly right until the last part, but you're being a little careless with your wording and possibly confusing people.
1. You can never tap lands "for no reason". You can only tap them to use their ability, which in most cases produces mana. Granted, this difference isn't as important with the removal of mana burn, but the point still stands - if you tap a land, you're doing it to add the mana to your mana pool.
2. You can tap lands and add mana to your mana pool whenever you have priority, and it doesn't have to be to pay the cost of a spell or ability. That's what 'floating mana' is.
3. Mana abilities don't use the stack and thus cannot be responded to or interrupted. Their effect happens immediately.
4. The result for the purposes of this card, and any other cards that tap lands is this: if you cast something like Early Frost during your opponent's main phase, he can tap the lands to produce mana in response, and then subsequently use the mana to cast whatever he wants after Early Frost has resolved. In which case you're an idiot and you just wasted a card. The proper way to play this card, on the other hand, is to cast it during their upkeep. They can still tap the lands for mana in response, but they'll only be able to use it to cast instants. Otherwise, it will empty at the end of the upkeep and those lands will be unavailable for their main phase, which is what you wanted. Hope that helps.

73571: Early Frost.author: Ragamander
73571: Early Frost.text_parsed:
This is an interesting card.

I see its main use as being a way to stop control decks from countering early spells. Casting Early Frost during the upkeep of their second or third turn will keep them off the mana for Counterspell or Mana Leak on your third or fourth turn, which could be critical for quick-but-vulnerable combo decks. It can also keep multicolor decks from generating two mana of a single color (for powerful, mana-intensive sorceries, such as Wrath of God or, heaven forbid, Mind Over Matter) until they have at least FOUR sources of that color of mana.

Would be interesting if it were reprinted in Type-II. Would be fun and usable in casual with Isochron Scepter for continual lock-down.

73571: Early Frost.author: The_Murderauder
73571: Early Frost.text_parsed:
@Shabroky: Neither. Activated abilities that add mana to your mana pool (such as those included on almost every land, as well as cards like Llanowar Elves) are quite aptly called "mana abilities" and don't use the stack. As such, they can't be responded to. Similarly, paying the cost for any spell or ability (such as sacrificing a creature, paying life, tapping a permanent, or, most commonly, using mana that was just added to your mana pool) can never be responded to.

So, your opponent could not have legally attempted to deprive you of mana by casting Early Frost. You've already tapped the lands, gotten the mana, and paid the cost of the spell before he has the chance to do anything. He could still target the lands you used to get the mana to cast the spell, but they would already be tapped, and Early Frost would essentially do nothing.

@nammertime (and Shabroky): you don't "tap" mana. You add mana to your mana pool by "tapping" lands and other permanents with mana abilities, or playing a card such as Seething Song that adds mana to your mana pool. You can spend any of the mana in your mana pool to play spells and activate abilities until the end of the current step, when all mana pools empty (unless another effect like Upwelling says so).

And @Shabroky again: If you ever do find yourself in a situation (not like this one) where you discover that you couldn't have legally cast a spell (like, say, "Oh darn! I needed 3 red mana for that Violent Ultimatum, but I overlooked the fact that I only have 2 Mountains"), then a number of things can happen, depending on how serious the game is. Technically, in an official, sanctioned game, it would be up to a judge to decide, and you would probably be issued a game loss, or maybe even a match loss. If you're just playing with some friends or something, they'll probably just let you take it back. We all make mistakes!

The rules involving the speed of mana abilities and when costs are paid can be confusing for those who are unfamiliar.
Hope this has helped!

73587: Rude Awakening.author: Nickkom
73587: Rude Awakening.text_parsed:
I won't deny that entwining this card makes for a really powerful play.

But, when would you ever come across a situation where you would NOT entwine???

If I have 5 mana and I cast this to make all my forests 2/2s, they will be tapped and cant' attack. Otherwise, I just untap all forests and its like I never did anything, except I have another sorcery in the graveyard.

Even if I had something like 10 forests and tapped them all then cast this to untap them all, I get a net of 5 mana. I guess that's okay, but how often do you have 10 forests out and would really need to put 15 mana in your mana pool rather than create 10 2/2 creatures? It just seems useless.

Something like tooth and nail has use for each choice AND an even better use for entwining. THis card only seems useful if you entwine it.

This + Maze of Ith - for all intents and purposes, stops you getting attacked.

@Burn929 - an old comment so you may have learnt this by now, but trying to tap down an already attacking creature does nothing. 73925: Eyes of the Watcher.author: Nucleon
73925: Eyes of the Watcher.text_parsed: I put this in my EDH deck, and I like it quite a bit. Comparing it to the Top is obvious, but the real power is when you have it and this out at the same time. Reliable Scry effects combined with the Top is a potent combo, especially in larger multiplayer groups where your turns aren't as frequent. Crystal Ball isn't as good, I think. This costs less per activation, and is harder to get rid of. Although, it gives up reliability in exchange. If you run blue and have a bunch of instants and/or sorceries, try proxying this in and see how it works.

73926: Skullcage.text_parsed: Run this with a discard deck, so once they have no more cards to discard they're still taking damage.

73926: Skullcage.author: Mode
73926: Skullcage.text_parsed:
This card should be able to find use in a deck that runs some discard effects - Megrim will be far more preferable, though.

I also thought about using it in a deck running Underworld Dreams and card drawing effects, but this requires to make your opponent keep more than four cards in hand - which is pretty hard to achieve, and will also raise the possibility that he/she draws a response for the Skullcage. Even if you should be able to do so, e.g. with a Stasis deck, Eboni Owl Netsuke will do a better job then, therefore i guess you can forget about that use.

But aside from that, this card can be useful in general too, since your opponent won't always want to keep at least three cards in his or her hand to prevent the damage since he/she considers playing the cards in hand to be worth more than taking the damage.

73927: Lantern of Insight.author: KikiJikiTiki
73927: Lantern of Insight.text_parsed:
As far as my searching and knowledge reveals, this is one of only two non-unset cards that causes all players to play with the top card of their library revealed. The other, Field of Dreams, is mostly obsolete in comparison to this.

Works fantastically with the clash mechanic, but can also be utilized with cards like Djinn of Wishes and Summoning Trap for you, or Cerebral Eruption and Telemin Performance against your opponent.

Psychic Battle also seems like a good idea.

73927: Lantern of Insight.author: Mode
73927: Lantern of Insight.text_parsed:
Really liked this card ever since it came out. Although it can be destroyed easier by red and black, you can get it easier than Field of Dreams since it's a 1cc artifact (via Trinket Mage for instance)

The second ability is merely an expedient since it will end the insight and isn't reliable to give better results,
but it's for free and that's also what gives this card a use by itself without building around it.

@KikiJikiTiki: Don't forget about the lame and obvious choice for the second ability, Cosi's Trickster ;)
It would at least be useful if you draw a second lantern.

People underrate shuffling. If your mana screwed, it can save your bacon. If your oppoment is about to get a really good card, it screws them over, and might do other things as well.

Its a double-edged sword, but if you in a situation like mana screw, you have nothing to lose. It might just save your day.

and hell, this thing is only 1 mana, and an artifact, to boot. so you might as well use it in your artifact deck if you have it. hell, you could do worse, like Brass Gnat.

73928: Spinal Parasite.author: Mode
73928: Spinal Parasite.text_parsed:
-1/-1 is a cool idea, but it really wasn't necessary on this creature.
0/0, 1/1 or even 2/2 for that guy would have been still far away from being broken.
Even in a triple-colored deck the Parasite could become no larger than 2/2 and you could activate the ability once only and thereby even kill him.
That's certainly not worth a five-mana investment, i'd rather play a simple Medicine Runner, Vampire Hexmage or Clockspinning instead.

@Zulp: I don't think so. For five mana you are offered a broad selection of burn spells which will easily remove more than one or two tiny loyality counters, and the aforementioned Vampire Hexmage does a better job if you're going the direct way of loyality removal, too.

@Draugnor: Once your opponent made a big guy out of this creature, he could have made an even bigger threat out of another one. (By the way, i doubt it was 18/18 when considering that Cranial Plating only gives +1/+0 and does not help activating this creature's ability either)

@mn6334: The ability does synergize with Persist creatures, yet there are simply a lot of better options for doing so (Juniper Order Ranger, Heartmender or similar cards that even allow loops.)

73928: Spinal Parasite.author: Tera_GX
73928: Spinal Parasite.text_parsed:
Aw, I was a bit excited to see the unusual -1/-1 base, but I do agree it is otherwise quite a shame. I have a powerful counter-manipulating artifact deck, but this guy would not be the candidate for most of my effects.

It's greatest use would be if I were using my counter-manipulating deck, and my opponent started taking control of some of my power cards, then he could start destroying me with this card. But that scenario makes little sense. All "real" good qualities of this card are covered by other things in the kind of deck it would go in.

I can perpetuate Persist a lot better with other cards than can this guy, as well as robbing my opponent of his counters.

73928: Spinal Parasite.author: tcollins
73928: Spinal Parasite.text_parsed:
I think it would've worked if the card instead was designed as:
Spinal Parasite {4}

Sunburst, Sunburst
Remove two +1/+1 counters from Spinal Parasite: Remove a counter from target permanent.
-1/-1

That way it enter the battlefield as a 7/7 for {WUBR}/{WUBG}/{WBRG}/{WURG}/{URBG} at best.. i understand that's well above the curve, but Fusion Elemental is an 8/8 for {WUBRG}, and is less susceptible to removal because he retains his colours and isn't subject to cards like Naturalize. I know that this is probably too powerful, but as is Spinal Parasite is mediocre at best, sadly this is the often the case with most of the sunburst cards.

73928: Spinal Parasite.author: ICEFANG13
73928: Spinal Parasite.text_parsed:
@ chives5602

I believe in power creep a bit, I feel like newer cards clearly are better than older cards. Its not something I love, but it is what it is, magic will either go up slowly or quickly. Cards at the same power level means a dead game, and it is for $$, its not like anyone wants Magic to die.

What you said makes no sense whatsoever, I don't like players that just complain that power creep isn't here, it is, but I also don't like players who complain about power creep.

So lets see, you spend WUBRG to deal with 3BB, nice. I mean if this creature is as good as you say it is, then it should deal with that easily, I mean you spent all five colors on it.

Ok so you have a 4/4 that costs way more than his 3/3 (because of color weight). So you got him!

Well except Ob Nixilis, the Fallen has Landfall, so after 1 land, its a 6/6, and you aren't winning anymore.

Oh wait, you already counted that. Ok so Spinal Parasite removes 2 counters to remove 1 of his? ooooo scary! What a sick card.

So you are left with a 0/0 (which is +2/+2 from an equipment that you didn't name, the cheapest being Copper Carapace, so you invested another 4 mana into it, WUBRG4 =/= a pathetic 2/2 with no abilities, also it can't block, so yeah) vs his 4/4 which gets bigger and saps your life for each land, even if he didn't play any more lands, you've already wasted so much mana and turns and cards on this sad 2/2 that can't block.

Oh one more thing, never say something is better when you equip it, if you hadn't equipped it, is there any doubt this card would be worthless in the situation you provided? Almost every card gets better when you equip it with any equipment.

Yes there is power creep, good job on proving it with such a great example.

If this card was even a 1/1, or a 1/1 that came into play with a +1/+1 counter would it be good? Kinda maybe, a 7/7 for WUBRG that you can put at 1/1 and remove three counters? At least its something

Choose a better card for your arguments on power creep, this card was outclassed a long time ago.

Edit, after reading what you say on other cards, I'm shocked, you play a modular and sunburst deck, so you are using all of your creatures to keep his one back? You must be one of those players that plays with the obvious good cards and for some reason a bunch of horrible cards in a vintage deck and complains when you lose because of your deck building 'skills'. They probably cheated.

73928: Spinal Parasite.author: Ferlord
73928: Spinal Parasite.text_parsed:
Sunburst isn't a good ability. I know there'll be some people who'll defend Sunburst to the nth degree, but there are so few sunburst cards that are worth the investment and effort.

One thing I'd like to rationalize is the more colours you need, the harder it becomes. This should be obvious, but some people I know don't think so.

Imagine there was a 0/0 creature that came into play with 5 +1/+1 counters and had : Double the amount of counters on it. Would you think that to be a good creature? Of course you could abuse the counters, but you need to usually wait a turn before that happens. Personally, I'd think it to be an over-costed creature that is rather slow.
This is Solarion.

Imagine another creature that was a -cost 3/3 that came into play with 5 +1/+1 counters and had ", remove a counter from this: destroy a creature" and ", remove a counter: return this to your hand". I'd say it's overcosted as well, and multiple other cards that cost less can do it better (Avatar of Woe, Visara the Dreadful, Royal Assassin (to a degree), Intrepid Hero (again, to a degree)).
But then, I hear praise for Suncrusher.

Don't get me wrong: Clearwater Goblet is an actually good Sunburst card and Pentad Prism is always a necessary piece of some weird combo deck that can win on turn 2 or 3. But most of them are overcosted cards that if they showed you what their colours really were, you'd think they weren't that good.
